title: Before 1 January 2020, will a NATO member formally invoke Article 4 or Article 5 of the Washington Treaty in response to actions taken by Russia?
preds: At this monent the time is too short for making such a decisions
Late to the question, but no - not this year.
Russia is holding further activity at the moment. Sanctions are biting the economy  and she can’t afford any more antagonism.

Not much time remaining. Had thought Turkey would be a possibility but given developments there, seems very unlikely. Hard to see another NATO member doing that in the current environment and timeframe.

Before 1 January 2020, will a NATO member formally invoke Article 4 or Article 5 of the Washington Treaty in response to actions taken by Russia? Russia's plate is full with ME adventures at the moment.
Putin's got enough on his plate
Russia is facing domestic challenges making it unlikely to make controversial international moves
bringing down a bit as end date closer
They may pass it, Russia will veto it. So, it doesn’t really matter.
Russia gaining friends in US, UK, Italy, Turkey....
Russia is already vastly overstretched and on the verge of a political crisis. There is no logical way this will happen, as Russia needs to solve it's more important issues at hand first.
Very very unlikely. When Turkey shot down one of Russian airforce, nothing happened. Let's cross fingers.

The text of Article 4 of the North Atlantic Treaty stipulates that "The Parties will consult together whenever, in the opinion of any of them, the territorial integrity, political independence or security of any of the Parties is threatened" whereas Article 5 goes as follows: "The Parties agree that an armed attack against one or more of them in Europe or North America shall be considered an attack against them all [...]"  So far, Article 5 has only been triggered by the USA after the events of 9/11. It is unlikely that any NATO country would have the necessary capabilities to demand a war against Russia. As things stand, it is extremely unlikely that Russia will attack a NATO member state, as the Kremlin now prefers to attack Western countries in the cyber realm, through malware, disinformation campaigns, election meddling and so on.  Article 4 is the one that is more likely to be triggered (that article 5, that is). That is because of rising tensions among Russia and Western countries. At the moment, NATO suspended practical cooperation with Russia due to its aggressive actions in Ukraine, but channels for political dialogue are still open. The NATO-Russia Council, an important platform for dialogue, has not been suspended. Therefore, it seems like there is still will to maintain at the very least the status quo. There are currently no tensions on the Eastern border of NATO that could escalate to a threatening scenario. Many of my colleagues pointed out the fact that Turkey might be the member to take such a step. However, I believe it is unlikely iven its strategic position and the fact that Turkey-Russia relations have improved. Turkey is now basically playing both sides, by currently having military personnel in Russia learning how to operate the new surface-to-air missile system that it has just purchased from the Russians. While this is not a proof of hostility to the West, it is a realist position that secures the country's best interest.  Foreign Minister Mevlut Cavusoglu said in a news conference: "Our neighbors are not Mexico and Canada like America's neighbors. There have been serious threats in our region and we need to take necessary steps for Turkey's interests."
This shows that Turkey's actions are so far aimed at maintaining the status quo. 
This fact also implies that it would probably not take Georgia's part in a case in which Russia deploys troops or otherwise jeopardises the territorial integrity of Georgia. The only real possibility would be in the case of a trackable cyberattack with high impact, directed at a NATO member state. It certainly does have the capability to do so, but whether Putin would actually go through with such an offence is very questionable. It seems like Putin's style is to resort to remaining in the shade and publishing fake news.

UPDATE 13.06.2019 The initial forecast stated that “the deployment of allied troops along the eastern border of the NATO (especially the Baltics) decreases the probability that Russia would try to use the infamous “little green men” tactic as it did in Ukraine”. The two main reasons are that an increased military presence along the border would decrease the area where insurgent actions could be performed, and it would also increase the likelihood that insurgents would confront NATO troops sooner than later, thus, raising the probability of an open hostile conflict between Russia and the NATO (accordingly to Art. 5 & 6).  Based on this assessment, the deployment of 1’000 US troops in Poland would result in a decreased likelihood for Russian backed insurgent actions. Furthermore, the reactivation of the 2nd US fleet (responsible to patrol the North Atlantic and the Arctic region) and the upcoming joint fleet exercise in the Baltics (aka. BALTOPS) would furthermore decrease opportunities for Russia to conduct hidden military operations. However, this is the rationale of Western ‘hawks’. Indeed, it is likely that Russia will respond to the recent deployment of US troops by stationing own troops in Belarus as it did in the past with the deployment of intermediate-range ballistic missiles as a response to NATO’s expanded presence along the Eastern and South-Eastern border of its “alliance territory” (NATO, 2019). This accumulation of military resources on each side would increase the likelihood for further tensions (as all involved counterparties feel threatened in their national security), as well as, the uncertainty of severe or lethal collisions by accident. Two indicators tend to support the latter argument of increased tensions through the militarization of eastern Europe: a) military exercises expand regarding the number of participating military personnel and hardware in the last 10 years; b) incidents between forces above the Baltic Sea, Black Sea and the Mediterranean.  Another aspect to assess is if NATO members, other than the US, may change their behaviour based on recent events. There are again two possible scenarios which have an opposing effect on each other. On the one hand, the reactivation of the 2nd US fleet, deployment of troops and the upcoming BALTOPS may be perceived by NATO members as a sufficient signal of US commitment to the alliance which boosts the NATO credibility and its deterrence towards Russia. On the other hand, this renewed commitment of the US could tempt eastern NATO members to take a more aggressive and provoking stance against Russia, hence, increasing tensions and the likelihood for a conflict (in whatever form). The result might be the invocation of Art. 4 or (less likely) 5.  So far, this update focused on the deployment of military resources and its likely influence on the behaviour of Russia, the US and NATO members. Therefore, this paragraph focuses on statements made by Trump and Putin. Indeed, both country leaders declared their interest in normalizing US-Russian relations. Nonetheless, Putin admits that the current trend is one of deterioration. The US government approved the deployment of new military assets and the introduction of new sanctions despite Trump’s statement. As a result, the stressed commitments in favour of normalization should be overestimated concerning the other trends mentioned above.  In the end, the reallocation of military resources by each side to deter the other party indicate that the US-Russian relationship won’t normalize soon, despite contradicting statements of the country leaders. Therefore, the probability should be adjusted by 5% in favour of an invocation of Art. 4 or 5. Future updates will focus on the activities of non-US NATO members to assess if these tend to become more confrontational or passive-defensive towards Russia.   Source:

Considering the historical data on the matter one finds that article 4 has been invoked four times, one time involving Russia. When Poland in Match 2014 chose to invoke the article on the basis of the rising tensions in Ukraine. Article 5 has been invoked once, by the US following the events of 9/11. Based on this data one can state that there is a very low probability that either of the articles will be invoked by the 1st of January 2020. There seems to be a rather high threshold among the NATO member state in general to invoke the articles, meaning that a serious rise in tensions or a single/number of serious events would need to occur before the states would even consider invoking.   As several of my classmates have pointed out the chance that article 5 will be invoked in regard to Russia is especially low, based on the sphere of international politics. Considering the fact that one knows that Russia is especially focused on states like Georgia and Ukraine, who are not NATO members, nor will become so before the 1st of January 2020.    With article 4 on the other hand, there are more scenarios that are likely to happen which will lead to the article being invoked, however, I would like to stress that the probability is still low. Over the past few years tensions between “the West” and Russia have begun to rise in specific areas, such as the Artic, disinformation campaigns, cyber-attacks and so on. Especially scenarios including disinformation campaigns and potential cyber-attacks draws my attention in regard to article 4. Many NATO states will over the course of the next half year seen elections in all forms, were most of the state have stressed the importance of limiting disinformation campaigns and cyber-attacks especially concerning Russia. If one of the states were to observe such a campaign or a cyber-attack with connections to Kremlin, article 4 could potentially be invoked. However, it is a difficult situation as it can be hard to find hard evidence of Russia’s involvement in such attacks, which again means that invoking the article without proof could sour the already somewhat difficult relations NATO and its members have with Russia. This is why I still believe that the likelihood of any of the articles being invoked is extremely low, and why I have set my forecast at a 5%.      - https://www.bbc.com/news/blogs-trending-48296557
- https://www.vocaleurope.eu/should-we-expect-a-russian-disinformation-campaign-during-the-2019-european-elections/
- https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/opinions_166039.htm
- https://www.rferl.org/a/explainer-nato-articles-4-and-5/24626653.html

Update: 
European Elections has passed. There have been some reports of Russian disinformation (it is normal), but nothing huge, that could activate article 4 or 5. So reducing  the probability to half, as there are only have a year left and the EP elections are passed.

I believe that it is highly unlikely that a NATO member will formally invoke Article 5 in response to a military action taken by Russia, as like lined out by the Washington Treaty Article 5 is a response an armed attack by a non-NATO state and commits each member state to consider an armed attack against one member state to be an armed attack against them all. Article 5 has so far only been invoked once after the 9/11 terrorist attacks against the US (https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/topics_110496.htm). I do not believe that Russia will attack any NATO member state with armed forces within the next seven months, even though it is hard to predict. The one thing necessary to consider, however, is invoking Art. 5 on grounds of a cyber attack stemming from Russia against one of the NATO - members, as cyber attacks, as well, are included in Art. 5 of the Washington Treaty (https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/blogs/natosource/nato-updates-policy-offers-members-article-5-protection-against-cyber-attacks ; https://www.nato-pa.int/download-file?filename=sites/default/files/2019-04/087_STC_19_E%20-%20NATO.pdf). A cyber attack stemming from Russia is a credible threat (https://www.dni.gov/files/ODNI/documents/2019-ATA-SFR---SSCI.pdf). Yet, in light of the current publications of the Mueller report and the unveiling of Russia's probable involvement in the 2016 US elections a cyber threat is not very probable right now, considering Russia is already under watch. As well, Russia is in no direct conflict currently with any NATO member state which would give reason for attack (even though of course reason is not necessarily needed). Furthermore, if a cyber attack were to occur it is not necessarily clear where it originates from, hence even if Russia were to issue a cyber attack against one NATO member state it might not even be disclosed immediately. Overall, invoking Art. 5 seems unlikely to me.  On the other hand, Art. 4 of the Washington Treaty includes the consultation "whenever, in the opinion of any of them, the territorial
integrity, political independence or security of any of the Parties is threatened" (Art.4; https://www.nato.int/nato_static_fl2014/assets/pdf/stock_publications/20120822_nato_treaty_en_light_2009.pdf). Hence calling a meeting to consult about military matters. So far, this article has been invoked 3 times by Turkey, latest with reference to attacks in Syria in 2012,  as well as by Latvia, Lithuania and Poland in 2014 as response to the Crimea crisis. Since that crisis in 2014 the NATO-Russia relations have been deteriorating (https://sputniknews.com/europe/201906071075727696-nato-pays-very-close-attention-to-activities-of-russia-china-in-europe/). Yet, more concrete threats of Russia are rather posed against non-NATO members such as Georgia, after the Russia-Georgian war 2008, or the Ukraine, after the Crimean-Annexation. Moreover, considering that Article 4 has very rarely been invoked in the past, it is unlikely to happen. Here, again though I see the most probable reason for invoking Article 4 to be a possible cyber attack issued from Russia. Yesterday, 07th June 2019, Russian and US warships almost collided in the East Chinese Sea with both parties claiming the other is at fault (https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-48553568). It is relevant to keep an eye to these developments in the upcoming days, whether the US considers its territorial integrity, political independence or security threatened.  Overall, I still don't think it is that unlikely to happen, as actions with Russia in the past have been rather difficult to predict and many things can happen in 7 upcoming months. Therefore I keep my percentage between 15 and 20%, as I believe anything less would diminish the possibility too much.
Dropping a few points to stay below the consensus.

The NATO describes the Article 5 of its founding treaty as the commitment “to protect each other and setting a spirit of solidarity within the Alliance” (NATO). The Article 5 stipulates that “the Parties agree that an armed attack against one or more of them in Europe or North America shall be considered an attack against them all and consequently they agree that, if such an armed attack occurs, each of them […] will assist the Party or Parties […]” (ibis.). The article has been invoked once since the establishment of the alliance when the US called its NATO allies after the 9/11 terror attacks. The Article 6 complements Article 5 by providing clarity about what constitutes an “armed attack” (ibis.). It defines that an attack on the “territory of any of the Parties” and/or “on the forces, vessels, or aircraft of any of the Parties” justify the invoking of Article 5. It is extremely unlikely that Russia would dare to attack a NATO member as it would face the whole NATO alliance. Furthermore, the deployment of allied troops along the eastern border of the NATO (especially the Baltics) decreases the probability that Russia would try to use the infamous “little green men” tactic as it did in Ukraine. As a result, and despite recently growing tensions, this forecast assesses a X < 1% probability for this scenario to occur.  Article 4 stipulates that “the Parties will consult together whenever, in the opinion of any of them, the territorial integrity, political independence or security of any of the Parties is threatened” (NATO). Article 4 has been invoked only 5 times since the NATO treaty entered into force in 1949. The past invocations of Article 4 accorded with major conflicts such as the Iraq war, the Syrian conflict and the emergence of ISIS when Turkey requested its NATO allies to consult on behalf of its security. The 2014 invocation of Article 4 by Poland demanded a NATO consultation concerning the Ukrainian crisis. Especially the proven involvement of Russian armed forces caused discomfort along NATO’s eastern border. Particularly countries with Russian minorities suspect that Russia may use the same justification like in Ukraine (protecting its ethnical people from illicit prosecution) in order to undermine their sovereignty.  Indeed, the Russian Federation considers itself the official successor of the USSR. Therefore, it deems the NATO expansion towards eastern Europe, into former soviet states, as a crucial threat to its national security as this expansion policy implies a decline of Russia’s sphere of influence and leads to an enclosing of NATO troops. The vast area between Russia and Central Europe is seen as a decisive factor for defending against conquests such as the past invasions of Napoleon or Hitler. It could be argued that it is in Russia’s interest if the NATO dissolves itself or looses its internal coherence. However, it seems very unlikely that Russia would commit further actions which will significantly increase the already high tensions. Its economic and military situation (economic recession and the resource heavy demand of military involvements in several conflicts) doesn’t allow any further military confrontations. Other reasons for invoking Article 4 could be Russia’s strategy to secretly influence NATO members through cyber attacks, misinformation campaigns or the attempt to influence elections. However, these technics and goals have been existing for the last years and didn’t provoke the activation of the article yet. Instead, NATO countries started programs to counter these attempts which might reduce their threat in future years. Additionally, assigning a cyber attack to a specific source is very difficult and, hence, reduces the likelihood that a NATO member will use cyber attacks as legal basis for invoking Article 4.  This forecast assesses a low probability for an invocation of any article before the 1st of January 2020. Article 5 and 6 stipulate specific legal requirements which Russia is not likely to provide as it would result in open hostilities. Article 4 on the other hand could be triggered more easily. Nonetheless, it had been invoked only 5 times so far, and in 4/5 cases by Turkey without a direct connection to Russia, despite high tensions between Russia and the NATO. It seems very unlikely that this article will be invoked by a NATO member in a time of “frozen” conflicts rather than “hot” ones.   Sources:

	2. Does an invocation of the articles mean confirmation of joint action against a threatening party (in this case supposed to be Russia)?

With the change of President of Ukraine, where unexpected and unpredictable candidate for Russia has won, with his intentions unclear for the current Russian government, it is possible that Russia will make unexpected provocative or aggressive steps if it feels its interests and status quo are threatened. However, the possibility of this is not that high, as escalation might bring high costs for Russia and most probably will not be attempted. Hence probability 20%

I assume that there’s 5% chance that before 1 January 2020 a NATO member state will formally invoke Article 4 or Article 5 of the Washington Treaty in response to actions taken by Russia. Below are the major points on which I base my assumption. Under Article 4 of the North Atlantic Treaty a member state can call a meeting of NATO members to consult on the matters of “the territorial integrity, political independence or security of any of the parties” being threatened.  Article 4 has been invoked 4 times. Most of the time by Turkey and once by Latvia, Lithuania and Poland as a response to Russia’s intervention in Ukraine in 2014. The same can happen if Russia uses military forces against Ukraine in the upcoming months or decides to invade Georgia after 2008. I’ve read the forecast of @iwheeler stating that Turkey might invoke the Article 4 if Russia attacks Georgia. However, as a Georgian, I would highly doubt that, since in 2008 Georgia hasn’t received such support from Turkey and it can’t be expected in the upcoming years either.  Putin believes that in order to gain more internal support, he needs to bring victory to the country. Therefore, using military forces against non-NATO member countries might be considered as a common practice for him. Non-NATO states other than Ukraine or Georgia can be Sweden or Finland, yet another reason of invoking Article 4 against Russia. However, I would highly doubt that Putin would risk to go against countries like Sweden and Finland. Even though there’s been an article published by Foreign Policy of the former president of Georgia, Mikheil Saakashvili, stating that Putin is losing people’s support and his next targets are either Sweden or Finland, we should not forget that Saakashvili might not be objective and while assessing the actual threats he might be influenced by personal feelings and prejudices (another statement from me as a Georgian).  So, the major targets for Russia are still Ukraine and Georgia. The conflict between Russia and Georgia might be considered as a frozen one. 20% of Georgia is still occupied by Russia, moving the so-called “borders” further into Georgia and killing innocent citizens near those “borders”. The situation in Ukraine is also similar. I assume that there won’t be escalation to these conflicts before 2020. Hence, even though it’s become very frequent to invoke article 4, I still assume that in the upcoming months it is not going to take place.  Another reason for the Article 4 to be invoked might be cyber-attacks or interference in the upcoming elections of the European elections. However, I assume that after the outcome (publishing of the Mueller report and the tense relations between the US and Russia) of interfering in the US presidential elections, Russia will play its cards smarter.  Article 5 has been invoked only once by the US after 9/11. Under the Article 4 of the North Atlantic Treaty, each member state can perceive an armed attack against one of the NATO member states as an armed attacked against all of the members. Invoking article 5 against Russia means that Russia would attack one or several member states of the NATO. Current relations between the NATO member states and Russia exclude military intervention in the upcoming 7 months.  Sources:  https://foreignpolicy.com/2019/03/15/russias-next-land-grab-wont-be-in-an-ex-soviet-state-it-will-be-in-europe-putin-saakashvili-sweden-finland-arctic-northern-sea-route-baltics-nato/ https://www.rferl.org/a/explainer-nato-articles-4-and-5/24626653.html

It seems the base rate of invoking article 4 or 5 has changed substantially in the last 20 or so years compared with the early days of NATO. However, there is only half a year to go and not all the past events were triggered by Russia, so I will keep my probability low.

NATO Article 4 if mainly a political maneuver. When invoked, article 4 merely calls for a consultation of allies on a subject the invoked finds pressing. The idea being that a allies can offer help and NATO can possible come up with joint resolutions of actions in order to support each other. Meanwhile Article 5 is the famous one, where the invasion of one country is the invasion of all and all NATO members are obliged to provide assistance to the invoking state. For over 50 years, neither of these articles were invoked, but starting with 9/11 there has been a significant increase in invocation. Since Nato's inception, Article 4 has only been invoked 5 times. Once by Poland on March 3rd, 2013, in regards to the unfolding events in Ukraine and Russia's involvement. Then four times by Turkey, first on February 10th, 2003 due to the war in Iraq, next on June 22nd, 2012 after a Turkish fighter jet was shoe down by Syrian air defense systems, next on October 3rd, 2012 when 5 Turkish citizens were killed by a Syrian shells, then finally on July 26th 2015 following several terrorist attacks. Meanwhile, Article 5 has only been invoke once and that was famously by the U.S. in the wake of 9/11.  When looking holistically it seems rare for either article 4 or 5 to be invoked and while this is true of article 5, article 4 was invoked 5 times in just three years in recent history due to geopolitical conflicts. I think the possibility of an appeal to article 4 or 5 is very unlikely (7%), but I’ll consider them separately to analyse each implications.
Article 5 states that an attack against a State member of NATO is an attack against all of the members, and sets the possibility of collective-defence, using the necessary tools (military or not). So far in history, it has been invoked only once after the 9/11 terrorist attacks. Personally, I can’t imagine any possibility of a military or terroristic attack caused by Russia before the 1st January 2020, because no-one would gain any advantage from it, still less Russia. In spite of Russia being a global power, NATO is the most powerful military alliance existent which Russia has better not to challenge. Russia doesn’t have enough economic neither military power to face the eventual countermeasures taken by the entire NATO community, and I’m talking both about hard measures as military intervention and economic ones, like sanctions (which it is already suffering because of the Crimea issue). 
About Ukraine issue: a military intervention by Russia has already occurred (I’m referring to Crimea war), but Ukraine is not a NATO country and I don’t think is going to be part of it by next year. First of all, the domestic policy is too fragile now, the citizens are divided between pro-Europe and pro-Russia, plus the next president is likely to be Zelensky, quite close to Crimea requests and slightly filo-Russian. Neither the NATO would like to include it in its alliance in such a short amount of time and without any guarantee of stability in the country. Article 4 states the possibility for each member to ask for a NATO meeting to consult the members in case it feels its territorial integrity, independency or security threatened. Article 4 has been invocated only four times (most of them by Turkey) and only once against Russia. This article is objected of a very broad interpretation, indeed “members can bring any issue of concern, especially related to the security of a member country, to the table for discussion within the North Atlantic Council.” As we known, nowadays major threats to national security are no-more only the military ones, but a lot of others are included, regarding environmental, humanitarian, or energy security: that’s why invoking art. 4 from a NATO country is more likely to happen. Let’s check the various scenarios. Ukraine issue: what Russia does there can scare the countries of the area, historically threatened by Russia (Baltic states or Poland, which had already invoked article 4 in 2014 as a response to Russian intervention in Crimea). Cyber security issue: currently, the most likely threat that a NATO country could experience by Russia are cyberattacks. In 2016 US elections we have had proof of it and in EU exists a special task force to contrast such a phenomenon. The possibility becomes more real if we consider that in May there will be European elections, where Russia has the interest to interference in order to keep European countries divided. However, I still think is not enough a strong reason to bother the treaty. Artic issue: according to what we have learnt in the 1st semester, various Arctic states are contesting some territories and sea areas, because of the opening of new arctic routes and presence of natural resources. One of them, especially Norway, could invoke this article if Russia goes too far in its demonstration of power. Also, those countries seems to cooperate in order to don’t increase the tension. Gas supplies issue: 74% of the gas consumed in EU is imported by Russia, a card to play to blackmail Europe. In that case Europe could feel threatened. However, I don’t see it very likely to happen because most of the Russian incomes are from the gas exports, and without them its economic situation, already precarious, would worsen. Also, there are concretes evidence of Russian interests in trading with Europe, like the construction of Nord Stream 2.  Nuclear issue: after the withdrawal from the INF, we wait to see what will happen with the New START agreement between Russia and US. It’s quite clear that it will be renovated or extended but, in any case, the two powers will keep an agreement and there won’t be a tension escalation before 2020. I don’t see any point in threatening countries of a nuclear attack: doing that wouldn’t worth against a weak country and would be too dangerous against the US (we all learnt something from the Cold War, right?). Accidents: do you remember the Malaysia Airlines civil aircraft shot down from a land-based missile in 2014, while was flying over East Ukraine? In that occasion Ukrainian separatists and then Russia have been blamed. If something similar happens again in a NATO country or against one of its means of transport, maybe during some contested military trainings/intelligence activities, article 4 can be invoked. In conclusion, I believe all of these scenarios extremely unlikely, except for the ones regarding cyber and arctic threats. Sources:

First of all, I want to point out that the following analysis focuses only on the formal invocation of article 4 of the NATO charter. Article 5 pertains armed attacks against a NATO member, and I consider the probability of such event before 1 January 2020 absolutely unlikely. The last consideration derives from the facts that:
- article 5 has been invoked only once, by the US after 9/11. As such, article 5 has never been invoked after a direct attack from a country to a NATO member
- the scenario in which Russia decides to directly attack a NATO member is extremely unlikely, for the very reason that it's a NATO member and because of the very existence of article 5. It's not in Russian interest - or in any state's - to ignite the collective countermeasures linked to an armed attack to a member state, NATO is still the most powerful military alliace in the world, and in the foreseeable future the world military lead will be held by the US and the NATO system. (Probability: 0%).
Moving on, it is necessary to fully understand what are the possible reasons which could lead to a formal invocation of article 4. The latter is: "The Parties will consult together whenever, in the opinion of any of them, the territorial integrity, political independence or security of any of the Parties is threatened." (for the consultation, see https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/official_texts_17120.htm). This article is much broader in meaning in comparison with article 5: first of all, it refers to every member's opinion about what they feel threatening. While every state has their own "national style" in detecting possible threats deriving from their interests and positions, we can assume that a formal invocation of article 4 would follow a threat recognized among all NATO members as such. While there isn't a checklist of all threats considered as such on a NATO level, we know that "during the 1990s NATO significantly broadened the range of what it now considers to be security challenges: cybersecurity, instability beyond NATO’s borders, terrorism, energy security, health risks, climate change and water scarcity are explicitly mentioned in the 2010 Strategic Concept, something probably unthinkable only fifteen years before" (http://www.act.nato.int/images/stories/events/2015/acor/ac15_final.pdf, page 5. For an overlook on NATO's strategic concept, see https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/topics_56626.htm and https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/official_texts_27433.htm). With this insight, we can assume that, with the right motivation and drivers, any threatening behaviour Russia could assume in the next months against a NATO member could lead to an article 4's invocation. Basically, it's impossible to restrict the analysis this way. It is more useful to invert the question: which perceived threats against NATO members could be Russia responsible for in the next months?

Ukraine is currenlty under elections. Both possible future presidents - Petro Poroshenko and Volodymyr Zelenskiy - are, to different degrees, pro EU and pro NATO. Nevertheless, we can expect that for Ukrain to join NATO will take a while - the most probable elections' winner, Zelenskiy, is willing to make a referendum over joining NATO, which obviously will take time (https://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/ukraine/2019-04-02/will-comic-actor-become-ukraines-next-president). I started with Ukraine because it's the only country near the NATO influence zone affected by direct Russian armed violence. For the actual NATO member's analysis, I will try to outline which main threats they could perceive from Russia in the next months. 
Russia is one of the main Euroean energy supplier and, as already stated, NATO members can perceive as a threat the loss of energy security. This scenario is extremely unlikely for several reasons: the energetic dependency corresponds to a Russian economic dependency from energetic revenues, which would mean very bad Russian economic performance, which is something you don't really want when elections approach - even if Russian elections are questinable in matters of democratic procedures.  Moreover, Russia threatening Europe or actually blocking the supplies is a scenario we already saw (https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/07/world/europe/07gazprom.html) without the invocation of article 4. (probability: 0%).

Another source of threat could be about environmental security. Denmark is currently blocking Gazprom's North Stream 2 by advancing possible environmental problems linked with the project. Nevertheless, Russia has a plan B (https://russiabusinesstoday.com/energy/denmark-still-deciding-on-nord-stream-2-approval/) which will likely imply the same environmental issues (the pipelined would only not pass through Denmark's exclusive economic zone, but really near). Another source of perceived threats could arise from Russian military exercises, most of all for European countries near the Russian borders (all NATO members). If those countries feel threatened by the military display - which could be understandable with the Ukranian situation - they could invoke article 4. As military exercises are not foreseeable (and definetly not scheduled in documents I have the access to), I would say that it could be possible, but military exercises has never been motive of article 4's invocation (probability: 0,5%). 
The last two sources of possible perceived threat I could think of are interlinked, and, in my opinion, the most relevant. Russia is well known, or at least it's suspected, to have cyber camapaigns and intelligence operations aimed at influencing foreign countries' policies, most of all in the event of elections - one of the most direct influences you can have over a country's policy is by trying to make a candidate/party whose program is in line with your interests win the elections. Moreover, a NATO member, given the new broad threat dimension outlined in the aforementioned 2010's NATO strategy, could decide to invoke article 4 after an especially severe cyber attack, or if intromissions in national elections were found. The latter two possibilities, though, would be difficult to demonstrate to be Russian-led, and even so, they could not lead to the invocation to article 4 - a national investigation, a UN inquiry, or a bilateral peaceful confrontation could happen instead - (probability: 5.5%).

In the history of NATO, Article 5 has only been invoked once. It was invoked in response to the unprecedented 9/11 attacks — which at the time fell out of the realm of ‘normal’ global conflict. Russian actions do not fall out of the realm of ‘normal’. They are known, anticipated and somewhat predictable in the eyes of the international community. Given the base rate, and the implications of invoking article 5 — motioning possible collective response — this is considered highly unlikely.  The invocation of of article 4 however, has occurred five times — four times by Turkey, once by Poland. The latter, in 2014, occurred in response to Ukrainian-Russian tensions in Ukraine.  Late last year, tensions re-escalated dramatically after Russia seized Ukrainian ships and detained crewmen (which have reportedly been serving their sentence in Moscow) after tensions have been building for months (BBC 26 Nov 2018).  At the same time, Russia has supported Assad in Syria, been suspected of undertaking submarine activity in the Nordic countries, has been involved in undermining foreign democracies and conducted systematic campaigns of cyber attacks. All this has gone without any formal invocation of Article 4, indicating Russia must instigate a major activity in order to incite response through Article 4 — there appears to be a considerable level of tolerance to Russian actions to date.   Thus, given the low rate of invocation and considering that Russia’s more questionable activities are known and ongoing, it seems unlikely a NATO member will formally invoke Article 4 (or 5) before the end of this year. It is forecasted at 10% to allow for the possibility of an escalation that would incite real concern by a member.

Article 4 is intended to provide the opportunity for a NATO member State to call for a meeting with the 28 other member States, to “consult" when it feels its independence or security are threatened.
Article 5 is the core article of the Alliance, best summarized by the principle of “one for all, all for one” in the face of external threat.  Historically, article 4 was invoked four times and only one time it involved Russia. Poland invoked Article 4 on 3 March 2014 following the rise of tensions in neighbouring Ukraine. Article 5 was invoked only after the events of 9/11, by the United States — an act seemingly symbolic as the invocation of the article was against terrorism and not against one particular State. 
Taking the above mentioned as a basis for the forecast, there is too little chance that a NATO member will formally invoke Article 4 or Article 5 of the Washington Treaty in response to actions taken by Russia, before 1 January 2020. Indeed, there is a very low tendency among NATO member States to actually invoke the given articles.  Furthermore, in the face of the current state of affairs, there is a very low chance that the article 5 will be invoked any time soon. With regard to Russia’s territorial ambitions, for now they are very focused on Ukraine and Georgia that are not NATO members, or will not become NATO members before 1 January 2020.  The chances for the invocation of Article 4 are little higher in comparaison to Article 5, but remain quite low. There are indeed topics that could awaken anxiety at this time or in the following months. For example in the Arctic, despite the climate of cooperation, NATO seeks to show its muscles at the Russian-Norwegian border which irritates Moscow. In the case of an escalation,  one could imagine that the feeling of insecurity takes on a new dimension and thus consider an invocation of Article 4 namely from an Arctic State (Norway). But taking into account the interests of all Arctic States for cooperation in the region, it is more likely that there is no need for an invocation of Article 4 since the probabilities for military escalation are very limited. Other topics could be considered; most importantly, the cyber threat coming from Russia. The European elections are approaching and the Russian interferences through cyber means are very often suspected and feared by other countries. Moreover, the annexation of Crimea by Russia plus its ostensible reinforcement of (military) presence in the Baltic region, could lead to an invocation of Article 4 by Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania which adherence to NATO was mostly motivated by their geographical proximity to Russia.  Nevertheless, from the basis of the previous invocation of Article 4 & 5, there is a too little chance that a NATO member formally calls the Alliance for support in response to actions taken by Russia before January 1st 2020. https://www.rferl.org/a/explainer-nato-articles-4-and-5/24626653.html

GENERAL CONSIDERATIONS
Under Article 4, any member state can convene a meeting of NATO members to "consult" when it feels its independence or security are threatened. In practice, it has rarely been used and sends a strong political symbol to the greater world that NATO is concerned about a particular situation. Article 5 is known as the "one-for-all and all-for-one" article, the keystone of NATO as an organization. It states that an "armed attack" against one member is an attack against all and sets in motion the possibility of collective self-defense.
In theory, Articles 4 and 5 can only be invoked at the request of a NATO member. However, Article 5 has only been invoked once -- immediately following the September 11, 2001, terrorist attacks against the United States. Article 5 was not invoked in other cases when it theoretically might have -- such as the 1964 Gulf of Tonkin incident, the 1968 Pueblo incident, or the 1982 Falklands War -- because it was not requested. All major NATO decisions are made by consensus, so any invocation of Article 5 would require the consent of all 28 member. For instance, Turkey invoked Article 4 in 2003 during the Iraq War and NATO responded by improving security along Turkey's border with Iraq. But the decision was difficult, says NATO Watch Director Ian Davis, because some alliance members opposed military action in Iraq in the first place. However, apparently, the question refers just to “a formal invocation” of article 4 or 5 so whether if accepted or not is out of the scope of this forecast.   FORECAST 
Considering the historical pattern, the invocation of article 4 or 5 by a NATO member state in relation to Russia seems quite unlikely. In fact, Article 5 has been invoked only once in the aftermath of 9/11 (not because the US really needed help but to send a strong political message to the World). On the other hand, Article 4 has been invoked 4 times so far. However, only 1 time it was in relation to Russia and not even directly: it was invoked by Polonia in 2014 in relation to the Ukraine crisis (Ukraine couldn’t because is not a member of NATO, not yet at least). The other times article four was invoked by Ankara and Russia wasn’t involved.  Hence, with some basic statistics, we could easily assess that this event is highly unlikely (around 1-2% of possibility). However, statistics in forecasting is never enough.  Since the Russian unlawful annexation of Crimea, NATO-Russian’s relationship has been getting worse and worse. Nato has strongly increased its military presence nearby Russia’s borders and in Europe in general. Furthermore, the proxy war in Syria, where Russia and NATO/US sustained two opposite sides, did not help.  That said, I do not see at the current state of affairs situation involving Russia and a NATO member which might lead to the invocation of article 4 (and therefore even hardly article 5). The likelihood could increase with Georgia joining the NATO as it might happen, but January 2020 is too soon to have both its inclusion and already the invocation of one of the 2 articles.  However, what makes the invocation of these articles unpredictable is its high degree of subjectivity. In particular, I would not be surprised if the near future article 4 was invoked in relation to a presumed Russian cybersecurity attack or for some kind of campaign of disinformation. The upcoming European elections make such an outcome not impossible, albeit unlikely. It is true that it would mean broadening the interpretation of these articles far beyond the military threat but, after all, this is exactly in line with the broadening scope of NATO’s mission in recent years.  That said, it is also important to mention that NATO is currently facing a strong internal crisis, especially due to Trump’s delegitimization. Indeed, Trump wants allies to increase the military expenditure (at least until 2% of internal GDP) while countries like Germany have no intention to do so. Furthermore, Turkey and the US, regardless of being both in the North Atlantic Treaty, are now in a huge diplomatic crisis.  Concluding, if one of the two articles will be invoked, except in the evidence of a black swan like in 11/9, it will be in relation to article 4. I see the latter case possible, especially in relation to cybersecurity concerns. However, since the current internal delegitimization of NATO, I assess no more than a 15% chance of this happening in the current year.  Resources:

Base  rate for the forecast at hand are former invocations of Article 4 and 5: Article 4
The Parties will consult together whenever, in the opinion of any of them, the territorial integrity, political independence or security of any of the Parties is threatened. Article 4 has been invoked 4 times so far. Only once, when Poland invoked Article 4 on March 3, 2014, following increasing tensions in neighboring Ukraine, it was directed against Russia (https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natolive/topics_49187.htm). The other 4 times Article 4 has been invoked by Turkey.  Article 5
The Parties agree that an armed attack against one or more of them in Europe or North America shall be considered an attack against them all and consequently they agree that, if such an armed attack occurs, each of them, in exercise of the right of individual or collective self-defence recognised by Article 51 of the Charter of the United Nations, will assist the Party or Parties so attacked by taking forthwith, individually and in concert with the other Parties, such action as it deems necessary, including the use of armed force, to restore and maintain the security of the North Atlantic area.
Any such armed attack and all measures taken as a result thereof shall immediately be reported to the Security Council. Such measures shall be terminated when the Security Council has taken the measures necessary to restore and maintain international peace and security . Article 5 has been invoked only once in the aftermath of  9/11.  Thus, based upon its history, the invocation of Article 4 and 5 against Russia seems highly unlikely. Considering 70 years of NATO and one Russian-related invocation, one could - simplified - calculate a 1,4% probability of an invocation in 2019. However, it is worth to take a closer look at current relationships between the NATO and Russia. Relations has been tense. The Ukrainian conflict with Russia that caused the first and so far only invocation of Article 4 against Russia remain unresolved and lasts now already around five years. It was triggered in 2014 by Russia's support for separatists in eastern Ukraine and the annexation of the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea. Nato has since significantly increased its military presence in Eastern Europe. In 2017 it stationed around 4000 soldiers in the three Baltic states and Poland (http://www.spiegel.de/politik/ausland/russland-und-ukraine-nato-kuendigt-staerkere-praesenz-im-schwarzen-meer-an-a-1260711.html). In the Syrian war Russia supported Syria's ruler Bashar al-Assad in opposition to the Western alliance. A poison attack on the former Russian spy Sergei Skripal and his daughter Juliya has put a heavy strain on relations with the UK. Similar tense are relations between the US and Russia. Despite all these tensions and bad relations, the forecast at hand does not see any concrete threats at the moment that would motivate one of the NATO members to invoke Article 4 - leave alone 5.  However, threat perceptions are very subjective. Thus, the estimation of the likelihood of an invocation - particularly of article 4 - is aligned with a high degree of uncertainty.  Taken all of the aspects into account (The small invocation rate, tense relations, lack of concrete threat scenarios, high degree of uncertainty due to subjective threat perception of member states), the forecast at hand estimates the likelihood the articles to get invoked in 2019 as of 10%.

On the occasion of the 70th anniversary of NATO, which will be celebrated by the Alliance's 29 foreign ministers in Washington on April 4, it may be interesting to ask the question of an invocation of Article 4 or 5 by a member against Russia. Indeed, the current context of relations between NATO and Russia is more than tense. However, before starting the forecasting, it would be useful to recall what Articles 4 and 5 are, their uses and the events of the current context of NATO-Russia relations: Article Definitions:
- Article 4 : any member state can convene a meeting of NATO members to "consult" when it feels its independence or security are threatened (Source : https://www.rferl.org/a/explainer-nato-articles-4-and-5/24626653.html)
- Article 5 : the keystone of NATO. It states that an "armed attack" against one member is an attack against all and sets in motion the possibility of collective self-defense. (Source : https://www.rferl.org/a/explainer-nato-articles-4-and-5/24626653.html) Invocations of Articles in the past:
- Article 5 has only been invoked once, immediately following the September 11, 2001, terrorist attacks against the United States. The decision to invoke the article was made collectively by members states, apparently without a request from any individual member.
-Turkey invoked Article 4 in 2003 during the Iraq War and NATO responded by improving security along Turkey's border with Iraq.
- Article 4 invoked by Turkey after Syria’s shooting down of a Turkish jet in June 2012 and once again in October 2012 after Syrian attacks on Turkey and their counterattacks
- In April 2012, Turkish PM Erdogan considered invoking Article 5 of the NATO treaty to protect Turkish national security in a dispute over the Syrian Civil War.
- An Article 4 meeting was invoked by Latvia, Lithuania, and Poland in March 2014 as a response to the extraterritorial Crimean Crisis.
- Turkey announced plans to convoke under Article 4 an extraordinary meeting on 28 July 2015, ostensibly in response to the 2015 Suruç Bombing which it attributed to ISIS, and other security issues along its southern border
In total : 
- Formal : 3 Invocations of Article 4 (by Turkey only), 1 invocation of Article 5 (for 9/11, by all members of NATO)
- Informal (meeting) : 1 possibility of Article 5 (by Turkey), 2 possibility of Article 4 (1 from Baltic States and Poland, 1 from Turkey) Recent events:
- The annexation of Crimea in 2014 by Russia, a major point of contention between NATO and the country
- In 2016, NATO deployed four multinational battlegroups to ensure an "enhanced forward presence" in Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania and Poland. In 2017, these battlegroups became fully operational. More than 4,500 European and North American military personnel work in close collaboration with the defense forces of the countries concerned.
-Trump and his ambiguity with NATO, calling into question the usefulness of the alliance, and strongly insisting that each government carry its military effort to 2% of its GDP in 2024 at the latest (and of which Germany does not will comply, with 1.5% expected for 2024
- The largest military exercise in NATO's history in Norway in November 2018
- The dispute between Turkey and the United States, both members of NATO, around the Turkish will to acquire the Russian missile defense system S-400. On the eve of the 70th anniversary, Washington increased pressure on Ankara by suspending any delivery to the Turks in connection with F-35 fighter planes. Forecast:
It is therefore necessary for a member state to feel threatened its independence or security, or simply because it is under attack, for an invocation of these articles.
However,
Article 4: In practice, it has rarely been used and sends a strong political symbol to the greater world that NATO is concerned about a particular situation.
Article 5: The only use of this article (11 September 2001) was asymmetrical because it was not invoked against a particular state, but more generally against terrorism. So there is also a lot of symbolism in it.
It seems complicated, apart from an extreme threat, for a Member State to invoke an article directly against Russia, thus announcing an entry into the war between NATO (or at least some members) and Russia (for the article 5). As for Article 4, its invocation would crystallize tensions that were too strong and would necessarily lead to confrontation, which the two parties do not seek, more than the status quo.
It must also be remembered that Ukraine is not in NATO, so unfortunately the events in Ukraine can not be taken into account, except if it results in a threat to a Member State. It is therefore more likely of a status quo for the year 2019, than a rise in extreme tension to arrive at the formal invocation by a NATO member state of Article 4 or 5 against Russia.

I'm placing this as 4%. OUTSIDE VIEW: -Article 5 has been invoked once, in response to al-Qaeda's attacks on 9/11. More importantly, it has NOT been invoked in response to Russia. Therefore, the known probability of Article 5 invocations in response to Russia is 0%. -Article 4, depending on sources, has been invoked approximately 5 times -- but only 1 time in response to Russia (by Latvia, Lithuania, and Poland with the annexation of Crimea in 2013). Given that this question is asking if these articles will be invoked in the next year, I'm going to derive a probability estimate based on an invocation in any given year. I'm also going to impose a temporal floor of when Putin first rose to power in 1999. This, in my opinion, marks the beginning of when an invocation of Article 4 in response to Russia would be plausible, as the years preceding witnessed an amicable entente given the collapse of the Soviet Union. This equates to a probability of 1 instance in 19 years of Putin's leadership (~5.3%). -It appears there is a substantial threshold to be surpassed for any of these articles to be invoked: a direct and large-scale attack on a NATO member or its non-NATO neighbors. Despite the salience of recent events with Ukraine and the Kerch Strait, no invocation of Article 4 was witnessed.  INSIDE VIEW: -First, I find it highly improbable (99%) that Russia will launch a large-scale, military attack on a NATO member. This effectively precludes an Article 5 invocation in response to Russia. I will not belabor the reasoning and the academic research to support it, but the magnitude of coordination and cooperation amongst NATO members and the individual attributes of NATO members makes me strongly believe that any Russian attack would elicit a coordinated retaliatory response by the alliance. With this foresight, I believe Russia would avoid such an engagement. Moreover, there appears to be no reason for such a confrontation at this time.  Assuming that another direct and large-scale attack on Ukraine will invoke an Article 4 invocation: -It is my belief that Putin's attacks in Ukraine's Crimea region were spontaneously pursued (not premeditated). This appears to be compatible with similar events that transpired in Georgia in 2008. I view this as insightful for this forecast, given that this spontaneity was produced by an internal crisis, subsequently making a Russian advance to be viewed as auspicious by Putin. In other words, it does not appear that Russia acts under normal conditions -- only when domestic instability is pronounced in its target nations. At this time, I do not see sufficient domestic instability, meaning that I do not believe Russia views there to be an opportunity to make another advance. However, this could change quickly; I will have to keep monitoring.  -It is my belief that Russia, like any nation, will not make an advance if it anticipates future costs imposed by other nations. I believe that there was little evidence to betoken future costs for the annexation of Crimea. More of Ukraine's trade occurred with Russia than Europe, Ukraine produced its own military arms, Ukraine carried no security arrangements with other NATO members, and NATO was militarily inferior in the region of operation. However, this appears to be changing, as more military aid is being funneled into Ukraine by NATO members, the trade balance is shifting away from Russia, and greater communication is occurring between Ukraine and NATO counterparts.   -Finally, to address recent events in the Kerch Strait: it appears to me that there are no statements indicative of future Russian action. Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko has referenced a mobilization of Russian troops on the Ukrainian border. However, he was speaking at a military forum. Moreover, his poll numbers are low, which is problematic given that he’s a potential candidate for office in the upcoming March, 2019 presidential elections. Invocation of Article 5 is highly unlikely. It is not in Russia's interest to become involved in a hot war with NATO; though there have been debates about whether Article 5 remains a credible deterrent, the incentives are not strong enough for Russia to risk the possible consequences of an open attack on a NATO country. This is particularly true since there are other ways that Russia could meddle or otherwise destabilize NATO-member countries in ways that would not rise to the threshold of triggering Article 5. Article 4 is more likely to happen since it only calls for "consultation". It was invoked in 2003, 2012, and 2015 by Turkey, and 2014 by Poland. Turkey remains in a neighborhood where the course of events might give rise to a situation in which it would want to invoke Article 4; at the same time, increasing tensions with NATO and a rapprochement with Russia perhaps lessen the likelihood that Turkey would use this mechanism. The most likely countries to invoke Article 4 are the Baltics, particularly since there are NATO war games held and increased soldiers and equipment stations/deployed in more advanced positions. This increases the likelihood of accidental incidents that could trigger the need for consultation. The overall deterioration of Russia's relationship with the West and increasing mistrust raise the likelihood of an incident.

The chances that a NATO member will formally invoke Article 4 or Article 5 of the Washington Treaty in response to actions taken by Russia remain relatively low. Despite the tensions that currently comprise West-Russia relations, the post-Cold War military order remains relatively stable for now. If there is going to be a crisis, it would more than likely be relegated to the diplomatic sphere and there is a low chance that it will result in a military conflict. First, it is important to note that despite the loaded dialogues, NATO in general is not as combat ready to fight a large scale war like the one with Russia. Since the end of the Cold War, NATO forces in Europe have been greatly reduced despite the increase in member states. Most weaponry of NATO member states, including the US, has shifted to conducting successful operations against militarily weak states, as was the case in Yugoslavia, Afghanistan, and Iraq. The same reductions are also seen in Russia, whose forces pale in comparison to the height of the Warsaw Pact. A more important reason would be that both NATO and Russia do not have a strong will to fight. In terms of a military response, NATO merely stood and watched as Russia went to war in Georgia, annexed Crimea, and became militarily involved in Donbass. This has sent a clear message to Eastern member states that they may not be able to adequately rely on NATO for help in case of a military conflict. Even though NATO sent forces in Poland and the Baltics, this was done more for political rather than military reasons, as the forces sent are not nearly enough to adequately respond to a large-scale conflict. Russia, as well, is also unprepared for such as large-scale conflict. Although Russia has engaged in a massive military modernization program since the presidency of Putin, Russia's expertise has also been relegated to small scale conflicts such as in Georgia and Ukraine. Many cite the annexation of Crimea as a part of Russia's imperial ambitions, but even Russia is reasonable and knows that it would be economic and military suicide to attempt and restore Russia to the boundaries of the Soviet Union. Despite Russia's annexation of Crimea, Crimeans remain largely loyal to Russia and see Russia as a liberator and Crimea is also a very small territory. If Russia was to go on a campaign of Eastern Europe, it would not only be a huge military and economic cost that would lead to WW3, but even if Russia was successful, it would have to deal with a very hostile population. Russia is also mostly a paper tiger, as we have seen Turkey shoot down a Russian military aircraft, which did not result in a serious military conflict, despite the aggressive rhetoric from the Kremlin. http://carnegieendowment.org/2018/01/25/rethinking-danger-of-escalation-russia-nato-military-balance-pub-75346
https://www.economist.com/news/special-report/21735480-great-powers-seem-have-little-appetite-full-scale-war-there-room
https://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/31/world/europe/russia-putin-turkey-sanctions.html?mtrref=www.google.com&gwh=11B5B1FDCB625D8DD438B686EC0FC034&gwt=pay

Let's start with a look at the base rate. Argument 1: Russian aggression has only led once to invocation of Article 4 since 1991, and that was in 2014, on the back of the Ukraine crisis. 1/27 is just about an annualised 3.7%. There's just under 20 months to go so let's round down and call it 6% during the forecast period. As an alternative take however, if we say that Russia has been notably more assertive since 2008 (August War) then that’s one prompting of Article 4 due to Russian action since then which is annualised 10% * (20/12) = 16.7%. This seems a reasonable start to bracketing it. Since an assertive Russia is what we are dealing with, I am leaning towards the higher rate in the current international environment.  Things to consider: Article V is exceedingly unlikely to be used. It has only been invoked once, in extraordinary circumstances (9/11). I suggest NATO would rather avoid an invocation of Article V if at all possible as it seriously tests the solidity of the alliance – therefore even mumblings of it tend to see pre-emptive action taken to avoid the formal invocation. Key risk re: Russian action leading to an Article V call is probably in the Baltics at the moment, but it is important to remember that a small coalition of NATO forces including lead elements from Canada, UK, US & Germany (https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/news_146557.htm) are already stationed in the Baltic states & Poland - this would likely discourage minor incidents, and means the Russians would have to be prepared to become seriously aggressive if they wanted to act in this region in a way that would likely cause a trigger of Article V.  Article IV much more likely to be invoked. Four uses this decade. Only use of either article directly related to Russia, by Lat/Lith/Pol over Crimean Crisis/Donbass in 2014 (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ukraine-crisis-nato-meeting/poland-requests-more-nato-consultations-over-russia-idUSBREA221VS20140303). Obviously the possibility of an increase in Russian aggression remains however; given the current geopolitical situation what would Moscow do to aggravate the situation? A widening of Ukraine conflict or increased aggression in Baltics are both v. high risk for the Kremlin for low reward. The Crimean annexation which caused the first Article IV meeting was a deeply significant geopolitical move. In Russia it was a huge achievement for VVP. Abroad, it sent a chill through the former Warsaw pact nations. Note that previous Russian aggression in the Caucasus failed to provoke such a strong response. It's hard to imagine what strategic objective Russia would try to achieve that could bring about such a significant second shock. Of course that doesn't mean aggressive moves which lead to an Article IV meeting are not possible. Aside from simple recklessness, there are a number of  scenarios, albeit rather unlikely, that might lead down this route (e.g. Regime change/collapse in Belarus which necessitates worrying Russian troop deployments). It simply means that there is no obvious strategic objective at the moment that doesn't come with exceptional risk. Further agitation in Ukraine would be sufficient to unsettle Eastern Europe for instance, but it's not obvious what the objective of that could be. Regime change? To what avail?  Back in the world of currently manifest risks, while I do note the regular aggressive recon flights, border & cyber incidents etc, it's worth remembering that so far these have never necessitated an Article IV meeting, and they have been going on for some time. Unless they step up sharply in frequency/severity/targets I'm not instantly concerned for the purposes of this question.   Article IV could also be a reasonable response to a Salisbury style incident. The counterpoint to which is that surely the Kremlin will be avoiding nerve agents and their ilk for extra-territorial assassinations given the furore after the Skripal incident? Attacks like Salisbury are unusual, and it is the chemical agent that leads to a wider security context of A4/5, not the (attempted) assassination.  Article IV in Turkey: The Turkish front is still a possibility for an Article IV moment. Ankara is historically not afraid to call Article IV consultations, including when they lost an F4 to Syrian air defences (and as we know, this stuff can happen - how would Turkey have responded if Russia had shot down a Turkish jet in late 2015 instead of vice-versa?). Turkey has had 3 calls on Article IV (in 2 separate years) since 2011 (the start of the Arab Spring, which is linked to most of the issues) - this would suggest a rough (2/7) 28 - (3/7) 42% base rate (years/instances) … of course, none of these were to do with Russia, which calls the usefulness of that base rate into question. Still, it is an observation which highlights Ankara’s fondness for Article IV. A contraindication to the possibility of a Turkish invocation is that there have been generally warming relations between Russia and Turkey since the 2015 incident - but note that they do want opposite outcomes in Syria which could come to the fore as the conflict draws ever more towards a conclusion.  Integrating these factors is tough. Have the multiple calls on Article IV normalised its use in International Affairs in this decade, implying higher usage in the future? Is it simply a case of a unique set of circumstances or a trend that will continue? It is easy to be swayed by the availability heuristic towards a continuation of the current aggressive Russian posture. But tough to see what Russia would stand to gain or where/why/how they would escalate the current situation to the extent of the Crimea crisis, which is the only level of aggression that has previously spurred Article 4’s use. Given all this, and the fact that it is a reasonably long forecasting window, although I generally expect an easing of current Russia related tensions (essentially on the basis of a reversion to the mean - tensions are running unusually high at the moment) there remains a high risk of unforeseen incidents and this must be reflected in a raise above base rate.  Overall then, I think the crowd might be too low on this at the moment. I will start by using the higher baserate (17) and adjusting upwards, at least until we get a bit more clarity regarding the endgame in Syria. Will be also be watching Eastern Europe for clues. Not vastly upwards, I still think the odds are against invocation of either article – 24%, based on the additional risk factors as I am able to assess them at the moment,  with the hope and expectation that this could drift down back down towards (and potentially through) a steadily reducing base rate as the forecast progresses.
